required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: PreView: The Preventive Video Education in Waiting Rooms Program
clinical_study.official_title: PreView: The Preventive Video Education in Waiting Rooms Program

brief_summary.textblock: PreView is a novel tool that functions within the system in a busy clinic setting, integrates information obtained from a particular patient with provider alerts, is efficient, relieves the burden of time constraints and is tailored to the individual patient. The goal of PreView is to support and simplify the physician's role in promoting cancer screening.

detailed_description.textblock:
PreView is a multimedia interactive Video Doctor Plus Provider Alert intervention that assesses stage of change for cancer screening, uses an interactive Video Doctor who gives messages targeted to individual stage of change and individual barriers in a feasible and efficient manner, and generates individualized Provider Alerts. This innovative tool 1) focuses on all recommended cancer screening for a particular individual, 2) is tailored to an individual's stage of change and an individual's barriers to screening, and 3) has been pilot tested for feasibility but has not been tested in a primary care clinic setting and is thus a novel approach to increasing rates of cancer screening and discussions about cancer screening.
UCSF research staff will contact potential participants directly to confirm eligibility and request optional and voluntary participation.
PreView will remain at participating practices for a second year during the Maintenance Phase of the study. PreView will be placed in a conspicuous place, most likely in the waiting room. Eligible patients arriving for appointments will be encouraged by office staff and by signs to use it, but whether or not to use it will be completely optional. An information sheet about PreView will be available next to the PreView iPad for participants to review. A postcard with contact information for PreView staff will be placed next to the iPad for participants to provide feedback about PreView if they so desire. Their feedback is completely voluntary.
At each site there will be a designated 'office champion' who will ensure that the iPad is charged and functioning, will ensure that the printer is working and will be an on-site resource person.

primary_outcome.description: Data on receipt of screenings (including mammogram, Pap test, fecal occult blood test (FOBT), sigmoidoscopy (SIG), colonoscopy (COL), and prostate cancer screening) will be collected for up to one year after the intervention. The outcome data must be collected by chart review. The information collected will include the test received and the date it was done or that the discussion occurred.

secondary_outcome.description: Collected via computer during the initial assessment
Collected using the computer during the initial assessment and the post-visit assessment.
Collected using the computer during the initial assessment and the post-visit assessment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Readiness to be screened or to discuss screening
secondary_outcome.description: Collected using the computer during the initial assessment and the post-visit assessment.

clinical_study.condition: Interactive Intervention Assesses Stage of Change and Perceived Barriers to Cancer Screening

arm_group.description: Individuals in the intervention group will complete PreView, the Video Doctor Plus Provider Alert.
Individuals in the Control Group will watch a video about healthy lifestyles.

intervention.intervention_name: PreView, the Video Doctor Plus Provider Alert
intervention.description: PRE-VIEW is a multimedia program utilizing laptop computers to assess whether or not primary care patients are up to date with cancer screening, assess their stage of change and personal barriers to screening. The Video Doctor, portrayed by an actor, delivers brief, individually tailored stage and barrier specific messages that simulate the ideal physician-patient cancer screening conversation, using a library of digital video clips and complex branching logic. The program then provides the individualized information to the patient's physician in the form of a cue sheet or "Provider Alert."

Individuals in the Control Group will watch a video about healthy lifestyles, including information about exercise and healthy eating. This video was obtained from the Patient Education Institute. There will be no Provider Alert generated for participants in the control group.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- No prior history of cancer
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-English speaking

facility.name: John Muir Physician Network Clinical Research Center
